usages.pl: Are {parahw}gender{/parahw} and {parahw}sex{/parahw} the same? Usage Guide
pt: The words {it}sex{/it} and {it}gender{/it} have a long and intertwined history. In the 15th century {it}gender{/it} expanded from its use as a term for a grammatical subclass to join {it}sex{/it} in referring to either of the two primary biological forms of a species, a meaning {it}sex{/it} has had since the 14th century; phrases like {ldquo}the male sex{rdquo} and {ldquo}the female gender{rdquo} are both grounded in uses established for more than five centuries. In the 20th century {it}sex{/it} and {it}gender{/it} each acquired new uses. {it}Sex{/it} developed its {ldquo}sexual intercourse{rdquo} meaning in the early part of the century (now its more common meaning), and a few decades later {it}gender{/it} gained a meaning referring to the behavioral, cultural, or psychological traits typically associated with one sex, as in {ldquo}gender roles.{rdquo} Later in the century, {it}gender{/it} also came to have application in two closely related compound terms: {d_link|gender identity|gender identity} refers to a person's internal sense of being male, female, some combination of male and female, or neither male nor female; {d_link|gender expression|gender expression} refers to the physical and behavioral manifestations of one's gender identity. By the end of the century {it}gender{/it} by itself was being used as a synonym of {it}gender identity{/it}.{p_br}Among those who study gender and sexuality, a clear delineation between {it}sex{/it} and {it}gender{/it} is typically prescribed, with {it}sex{/it} as the preferred term for biological forms, and {it}gender{/it} limited to its meanings involving behavioral, cultural, and psychological traits. In this dichotomy, the terms {d_link|male|male:1} and {d_link|female|female:1} relate only to biological forms ({it}sex{/it}), while the terms {d_link|masculine|masculine:1}/{d_link|masculinity|masculinity}, {d_link|feminine|feminine:1}/{d_link|femininity|femininity}, {d_link|woman|woman}/{d_link|girl|girl}, and {d_link|man|man:1}/{d_link|boy|boy} relate only to psychological and sociocultural traits ({it}gender{/it}). This delineation also tends to be observed in technical and medical contexts, with the term {it}sex{/it} referring to biological forms in such phrases as {it}sex hormones{/it}, {it}sex organs{/it}, and {it}biological sex{/it}. But in nonmedical and nontechnical contexts, there is no clear delineation, and the status of the words remains complicated. Often when comparisons explicitly between male and female people are made, we see the term {it}gender{/it} employed, with that term dominating in such collocations as {it}gender differences{/it}, {it}gender gap{/it}, {it}gender equality{/it}, {it}gender bias{/it}, and {it}gender relations{/it}. It is likely that {it}gender{/it} is applied in such contexts because of its psychological and sociocultural meanings, the word's duality making it dually useful. The fact remains that it is often applied in such cases against the prescribed use.{p_br}Usage of {it}sex{/it} and {it}gender{/it} is by no means settled. For example, while {it}discrimination{/it} was far more often paired with {it}sex{/it} from the 1960s through the 20th century and into the 21st, the phrase {it}gender discrimination{/it} has been steadily increasing in use since the 1980s and is on track to become the dominant collocation. Currently both terms are sometimes employed with their intended synonymy made explicit: {it}sex/gender discrimination{/it}, {it}gender (sex) discrimination{/it}.

dt.t: From the moment that we chose her name … we have been, willy-nilly, {wi}gendering{/wi} our daughter. So has everyone else. (The men in my neighborhood will shadowbox with any apparently male toddler who staggers by, whether or not he is interested; they never shadowbox with female toddlers.)

dt.t: … at one stage we were going backwards in terms of {wi}gendering{/wi} toys. {ldquo}It sounds surprising, but analysis of toy catalogues shows that the {d_link|gendered|gendered:2} marketing of toys was more prevalent at the end of the 20th century than at the beginning,{rdquo} she [Dr. Rebecca Whiting] says.

… Erin McNeill, founder and president of Watertown-based Media Literacy Now, advocates for integrating media literacy into the K-12 curriculum. "Some parents won't notice or be concerned about the {wi}gendering{/wi} of products. It's important that all children have the opportunity to gain the critical thinking skills to understand how and why gendered ads target them," she says.

As the number of jobs for men dwindled, employers, reasserting man's role as bread-winner, came to define weaving, previously considered women's work, as men's work. … Geography is central to this process of the {wi}gendering{/wi} of jobs and more generally to labor market segmentation …

Davidoff and Hall's Family Fortunes, for example, has convincingly and influentially explored the ideological pressures that went into shaping the all-pervasive Victorian configuration of public roles and private spaces, and the relentless {wi}gendering{/wi} of work, religion, and family structure.

dt: {bc}to associate a gender or characteristics of a gender with (something)

dt.t: Keep in mind that fragrance nomenclature can get a bit muddled, especially since we spent so many years {wi}gendering{/wi} words like {ldquo}cologne{rdquo} for men and {ldquo}perfume{rdquo} for women.

For example, she notes that gender isn't just a fashionable modern preoccupation but an obsession of the eighteenth century when writers insisted on {wi}gendering{/wi} such dualisms as "reason" and "feeling."

And finally, we may see how authors explore the {wi}gendering{/wi} of political discourse; not only voices but political attitudes are encoded as masculine and feminine, and it is not unusual to find that female figures serve to criticize established political ideology.

dt: {bc}to analyze the role and effect of gender or sex in (something, such as a field of study or interest)

dt.t: Women's experiences of homelessness are different than men's. [Lisa] Spring says that {wi}gendering{/wi} homelessness begins with its very definition.

Geographers have long led the research on hazards and disasters, but few have focused on {wi}gendering{/wi} hazards, vulnerabilities, and disasters. … As the study by geographers Neumayer and Plumper (2007) demonstrates in data collected from around the world, more women compared to men are killed and injured in disasters.

Was Shakespeare gay? Is The Merchant of Venice anti-Semitic? How does mainstream reading differ from that of subcultural groups? How does the formal study of literature handle such questions? In this lively book, Alan Sinfield engages with topics such as the {wi}gendering{/wi} of literary culture, the sexual politics of psychoanalysis during the Cold War, and the history of cultural materialism …

dt: {bc}any of several surgical procedures that a transgender or nonbinary {dx_def}see {dxt|nonbinary|nonbinary|c}{/dx_def} person may choose to undergo in order to obtain physical characteristics that align with their {d_link|gender identity|gender identity} {bc}{sx|gender confirmation surgery||}

dt.t: Hormone therapy and {wi}gender-affirming surgery{/wi} are crucial parts of transition for many trans adults. Alleviating {d_link|gender dysphoria|gender dysphoria} and aligning gender expression with identity through these treatments can lower stress, reduce symptoms of depression and anxiety, and significantly lessen suicidal ideation.
Some people also identify as both nonbinary and trans. They may take hormones or undergo {wi}gender-affirming surgery{/wi}, but this doesn't take away from their nonbinary identity.
Many transgender individuals choose to undergo fertility preservation before their {wi}gender affirmation surgery{/wi} if having biological children is part of their long-term goals.

shortdef: any of several surgical procedures that a transgender or nonbinary person may choose to undergo in order to obtain physical characteristics that align with their gender identity : gender confirmation surgery —abbreviation GAS

dt.t: A new study has confirmed what others before it have found: {wi}Gender confirmation surgery{/wi} improves the quality of life of most who choose to undergo it.
{wi}Gender confirmation surgeries{/wi} for trans men and trans women, respectively, differ in scope and kind, giving patients a range of medical options to define transitioning on their own terms.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) does not require {wi}gender-confirming surgery{/wi} or legal recognition of a player's transitioned sex in order for transgender athletes to participate on a team that matches their identity …

shortdef: any of several surgical procedures that a transgender or nonbinary person may choose to undergo in order to obtain physical characteristics that align with their gender identity : gender-affirming surgery —abbreviation GCS

dt: {bc}a distressed state arising from conflict between a person's {d_link|gender identity|gender identity} and the sex the person was identified as having at birth

dt.t: I am a 24-year-old transgender woman, and I know {wi}gender dysphoria{/wi} very well. My distress over my physical body, my feeling that it doesn't always match up with my gender identity, often lurks in some far corner of my mind. It doesn't matter how well I'm dressed, how much I brush my hair, how many compliments I receive, or how well my hormone therapy treatment is working. When {wi}gender dysphoria{/wi} hits, it packs a punch.

The treatment for {wi}gender dysphoria{/wi} is often multi-disciplinary, combining the efforts of several behavioral health and medical professionals. … Non-operative treatment focuses on implementing psychosocial therapy and/or medical management with hormone replacement therapy. Operative treatments range from small cosmetic procedures to much larger genital transformation surgeries.

shortdef: a distressed state arising from conflict between a person's gender identity and the sex the person was identified as having at birth; also : a condition marked by such distress

dt: {bc}a state marked by positive emotions (such as happiness or excitement) arising from a sense of alignment between a person's {d_link|gender identity|gender identity} and {d_link|gender expression|gender expression}

dt.t: I would go on to experience this high, this {wi}gender euphoria{/wi}, countless more times over the next ten years. When I bought my first cologne. … When someone called me {ldquo}sir{rdquo} for the first time. Or the first time a barista wrote my chosen name on my iced coffee. I could go on. I was experiencing {wi}gender euphoria{/wi} long before I knew that I was trans—and long before I had language for my experience.

When asked to share an example of {wi}gender euphoria{/wi}, Cazares recalled the first time that he went shirtless on a beach. And when he finally felt comfortable entering a men's gym locker room. Those were defining moments, because they happened in spaces that had previously led him to feel frustrated and insecure about his body.

shortdef: a state marked by positive emotions (such as happiness or excitement) arising from a sense of alignment between a person's gender identity and gender expression

dt: {bc}the physical and behavioral manifestations of one's {d_link|gender identity|gender identity}

dt.t: People vary greatly in the extent to which they hold and convey gendered thoughts, feelings, and behaviors. {wi}Gender expression{/wi} refers to the way people convey their gender through mannerisms, behaviors, or expressions.
For most people, … {wi}gender expression{/wi} occurs so naturally it's unnoticeable. Except when {wi}gender expression{/wi} doesn't match traditional notions of the gender assigned at birth.

shortdef: the physical and behavioral manifestations of one's gender identity

dt: {bc}of, relating to, or being a person whose {d_link|gender identity|gender identity} is not fixed

dt.t: {wi}Gender-fluid{/wi} individuals prefer to remain flexible about their gender(s). Some dress in ways that reflect both genders at the same time, while others may express one gender one day and another gender another day.
The scene also reveals Stella as {wi}gender fluid{/wi}—someone who identifies as both boy and girl, sometimes skewing more heavily toward one gender than the other.
Some {wi}genderfluid{/wi} folks and drag artists use … "he," "she," or "they" based on how they're presenting.

utxt.t: {wi}Gender fluidity{/wi} is the ability to freely and knowingly become one or many of a limitless number of genders, for any length of time, at any rate of change. {wi}Gender fluidity{/wi} recognizes no borders or rules of gender.

shortdef: of, relating to, or being a person whose gender identity is not fixed

shortdef: a 2-year government-supported college that offers an associate degree

dt.t: Encouraging our families, friends and neighbors to get vaccinated adds layers of protection and helps us create {wi}community immunity{/wi}.
There is a level of vaccination that is needed to protect a community from an outbreak of disease. This is called "herd immunity" and sometimes, "{wi}community immunity{/wi}."

shortdef: herd immunity

dt: {bc}property held jointly by a married couple

shortdef: property held jointly by a married couple

dt: {bc}the spread of a contagious disease within a community

{bc}the spread of a contagious disease to individuals in a particular geographic location who have no known contact with other infected individuals or who have not recently traveled to an area where the disease has any documented cases

dt.t: Dr. [Anthony] Fauci, who is the top coronavirus expert in the country, said {wi}community spread{/wi} made it almost impossible to predict how many cases there will be.
… a 50-year-old New Rochelle man became the first known person in New York to contract the virus through {wi}community spread{/wi}.
In areas where {wi}community transmission{/wi} is high, schools may be closed and businesses may ask employees to work from home.

shortdef: the spread of a contagious disease within a community; specifically : the spread of a contagious disease to individuals in a particular geographic location who have no known contact with other infected individuals or who have not recently traveled to an area where the disease has any documented cases

dt: {bc}a system in which a farm is supported by local consumers who purchase prepaid {d_link|shares|share:2} in the farm's output which they receive periodically throughout the growing season

dt.t: And they run a {wi}community-supported agriculture{/wi} (CSA) program that this year will supply 400 local families with boxes of fresh produce … every week.

shortdef: a system in which a farm is supported by local consumers who purchase prepaid shares in the farm's output which they receive periodically throughout the growing season —abbreviation CSA

dt: {bc}the action of making an environment unsuitable or unsafe for use by introducing man-made waste

dt.t: Abandoned mining and milling operations are already implicated in {wi}pollution{/wi} of the river with toxic and radioactive waste products …
A three-year study … has indicated that the lake already is suffering from severe {wi}pollution{/wi} and that any additional development will exacerbate it.

dt: {bc}something (such as man-made waste) that makes an environment unsuitable or unsafe for use

dt.t: tested the levels of {wi}pollution{/wi} {gloss}=pollutants{/gloss} in the water

shortdef: the action of polluting; especially : the action of making an environment unsuitable or unsafe for use by introducing man-made waste
the condition of being polluted
something that pollutes; especially : something (such as man-made waste) that makes an environment unsuitable or unsafe for use

dt: {bc}artificial skylight (as from city lights) that interferes especially with astronomical observations

shortdef: artificial skylight (as from city lights) that interferes especially with astronomical observations

dt: {bc}annoying or harmful noise (as of automobiles or jet airplanes) in an environment

shortdef: annoying or harmful noise (as of automobiles or jet airplanes) in an environment

dt: {bc}the discharge of heated liquid (such as wastewater from a factory) into natural waters at a temperature harmful to the environment

shortdef: the discharge of heated liquid (such as wastewater from a factory) into natural waters at a temperature harmful to the environment

dt: {bc}a person who comes to a country to take up permanent residence
{bc}a plant or animal that becomes established in an area where it was previously unknown

shortdef: one that immigrates: such as
a person who comes to a country to take up permanent residence
a plant or animal that becomes established in an area where it was previously unknown
